title-group.article-title: Propeptide-mediated enhancement of hyperthermophilic subtilisin-like protease expression in Escherichia coli

contrib-group.aff: 1https://ror.org/0197nmd03grid.262576.20000 0000 8863 9909Department of Biotechnology, College of Life Sciences, Ritsumeikan University, 1-1-1 Noji-higashi, Kusatsu, Shiga 525-8577 Japan

abstract.p: Subtilisin-like serine proteases (subtilases) are widely used in industrial applications, particularly in the detergents, due to their robust catalytic properties. The hyperthermophilic archaeon Thermococcus kodakarensis KOD1 secretes TKSP, a highly stable subtilase capable of degrading pathogenic prion proteins under harsh conditions. TKSP is secreted as a precursor comprising an N-terminal propeptide (TKSPpro) fused to the catalytic domain. Although the TKSP precursor can be solubly expressed in Escherichia coli, TKSPpro, which transiently inhibits the catalytic domain, is rapidly cleaved. This releases active TKSP prematurely, leading to degradation of host proteins and severely limiting production yields. To address this issue, we developed a co-expression system in which the TKSP precursor is expressed alongside TKSpro, the propeptide of TKS, a homologous subtilase from T. kodakarensis KOD1. TKSpro is a potent inhibitor of its cognate catalytic domain due to its high structural rigidity and strong binding affinity. Co-expression with TKSpro enhanced TKSP expression levels by up to tenfold compared to expression without the propeptide. Crystallographic analysis of TKSpro in complex with TKSP lacking TKSPpro revealed that TKSpro binds complementarily to the catalytic domain, with the extended C-terminal region occupying the substrate-binding pocket. Mutational analysis further demonstrated that the structural rigidity and inhibitory potency of TKSpro correlates with TKSP expression yield in the co-expression system. This study demonstrates the importance of forming a stable inhibitory complex with an exogenous propeptide to suppress premature activation and enhance heterologous expression of cytotoxic subtilases in E. coli, providing a useful strategy for the production of proteolytically active enzymes.

sec.title: Supplementary Information
sec.p: The online version contains supplementary material available at 10.1186/s13568-025-01952-z.

institution-wrap.institution: Japan Society for the Promotion of Science

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Subtilisin-like proteases (subtilases) belong to the serine protease family S8 and are widely distributed across all domains of life (Siezen and Leunissen 1997). Due to their broad substrate specificity and optimal activity at alkaline pH, bacterial subtilases have been employed in detergents, as well as in the food, pharmaceutical, peptide synthesis and enzymatic waste treatment industries. Collectively, they account for approximately 25% of sales in the world enzyme market (Azrin et al. 2022). Hyperthermophilic subtilases are promising for further applications such as the decontamination of infectious prion proteins (PrPSc) from medical devices, where high stability under extreme conditions is required (Šnajder et al. 2015). We previously demonstrated that two subtilases from Thermococcus kodakarensis KOD1, TKS and TKSP, which are formally named Tk-subtilisin (Pulido et al. 2006) and Tk-SP (Foophow et al. 2010b), respectively, effectively degrade PrPSc in mouse brain homogenates at high temperature or in the presence of high-dose surfactants that inactivate mesophilic subtilases (Koga et al. 2014; Hirata et al. 2013). These properties make TKS and TKSP attractive for challenging various industrial applications where mesophilic counterparts cannot tackle effectively.

In the native hosts, subtilases are synthesized as inactive precursors containing an N-terminal signal peptide (pre-sequence), a propeptide and a catalytic domain. The pre-sequence directs secretion into the extracellular environment, where the secreted enzyme matures through three steps: (1) folding of the catalytic domain, (2) autocleavage between the propeptide and catalytic domain, and (3) degradation of the propeptides (Pulido et al. 2006; Foophow et al. 2010b). In the case of TKS and TKSP, their respective cognate propeptides (TKSpro and TKSPpro, respectively) promote folding but, upon autocleavage, form inhibitory complexes by blocking substrate access. Notably, degradation of the propeptide is often the rate-limiting step in subtilase maturation. Since the inhibitory potency of propeptides depends on their structural rigidity and binding affinity, engineering these features can modulate the rate and efficiency of subtilase maturation. This strategy has been demonstrated in subtilisin BPN’ (Kojima et al. 1998) as well as in TKS and pernisine (Pulido et al. 2007b; Uehara et al. 2013; Bahun and Poklar Ulrih 2023), which represent mesophilic and hyperthermophilic subtilases, respectively.

Despite their industrial potential, overproduction of TKS and TKSP in Escherichia coli remains challenging. When expressed in E. coli, TKS tends to form insoluble inclusion bodies, necessitating refolding for preparation of active enzyme. TKSP, by contrast, is expressed in a soluble form but is highly cytotoxic due to premature activation and nonspecific proteolysis, which severely limits its expression yield in E. coli. Although TKSP is produced as a precursor including TKSPpro, its inhibitory potency appears insufficient to fully suppress TKSP’s proteolytic activity and thereby cytotoxicity in E. coli.

To enhance TKSP production, we sought the propeptide that can inhibit TKSP more effectively. Our previous studies showed that TKSpro remains folded even after dissociation from the catalytic domain of TKS, in contrast to mesophilic subtilases’ propeptides, which become disordered upon isolated (Hu et al. 1996; Huang et al. 1997; Pulido et al. 2007a). This structural rigidity allows TKSpro to inhibit protease activity even at elevated temperatures (Uehara et al. 2013; Yuzaki et al. 2013). Given its high stability and strong inhibitory properties, we hypothesized that co-expressed TKSpro could effectively suppress the intracellular TKSP activity. This hypothesis is supported by our previous crystallographic studies on TKSP and TKS precursors, which showed that the catalytic domains of these subtilases complementarily bind their cognate propeptides in a similar manner, despite sharing only moderate to low sequence identities in the catalytic domains (32.8%) and propeptides (11.5%) (Supplementary Fig. S1) (Tanaka et al. 2007a, 2007b; Foophow et al. 2010a).

Here, we demonstrate that co-expression with TKSpro significantly improves TKSP expression in E. coli by mitigating its cytotoxicity. Moreover, X-ray structural analysis of TKSpro in complex with TKSP lacking TKSPpro highlights the importance of the C-terminal hydrophobic residue of TKSpro in inhibiting TKSP activity. Together, these findings establish that co-expression of a structurally rigid, heterologous propeptide provides a broadly applicable strategy to overcome the long-standing challenge of expressing cytotoxic subtilisin-like proteases in E. coli, and offers a framework for engineering efficient expression systems for industrially relevant proteases.

sec.title: Protein production and purification
sec.p: Expression vectors based on pET25b (Novagen, Madison, WI) for producing the precursor form of TKSP (TKSP1–640), its inactive mutant (TKSP1–640(S359A)), and an inactive mutant lacking both N- and C-terminal propeptides (TKSP114–539(S359A)) were previously constructed (Foophow et al. 2010a). For co-expression, the cDNA encoding TKSpro (Gly1–Leu69 of TKS) was cloned into the pCDF1b vector (Novagen), which is compatible with pET25b in Escherichia coli cells. TKSpro cDNA was PCR-amplified using primers designed to add NcoI and BamHⅠ restriction sites to the 5' and 3' ends of the gene, respectively (Supplementary Table S1). The resulting NcoI/BamHI-digested fragment was cloned into the pCDF1b vector. Expression vectors for TKSpro variants (pCDF1b-TKSpro(L69W), pCDF1b-TKSpro(L69A), and pCDF1b-TKSpro(G56E)) were constructed using the inverse PCR method with the appropriate primers (Supplementary Table S1). For individual expression of TKSpro derivatives, the respective cDNAs were re-cloned into the NcoI/BamHI site of the pET28a vector (Novagen). Additionally, the expression vector for TKSPpro (Ala1–Ala113 of TKSP) was constructed in pET28a using a similar strategy. The primers used are listed in Supplementary Table S1. DNA sequences were verified using T7P and T7T primers (Supplementary Table S1). For protein expression, E. coli C43(DE3) (Lucigen, Middleton, WI) was used for co-expression of TKSP and TKSpro derivatives, while Rosetta 2(DE3) (Novagen) was used for individual overproduction of TKSpro derivatives and TKSPpro. Protein expression was induced by the addition of 0.5 mM IPTG, and cells were cultured at 17℃ for 16 h. Cells were harvested, washed with 150 mM NaCl, and disrupted by ultrasonication in the lysis buffer (20 mM Tris–HCl, pH 7.5). TKSpro and its derivatives were purified as described previously (Uehara et al. 2013; Pulido et al. 2007a). Briefly, supernatants from the disrupted cells were collected by centrifugation at 48,384 × g for 60 min and loaded onto a HiTrap SP HP column (Cytiva, Washington, D.C.) equilibrated with the same buffer. Proteins were eluted with a liner 0–1 M NaCl gradient, and fractions containing target proteins were collected and dialyzed overnight against 20 mM Tris–HCl, pH 9.0 at 4℃. The next day, proteins were loaded onto a HiTrap Q HP column (Cytiva) and eluted using a liner 0–1 M NaCl gradient. The eluted proteins were dialyzed against 20 mM Tris–HCl, pH 7.5, and stored at 4℃ until use. For purification of TKSP114–539(S359A), contaminating proteins were precipitated by incubating the lysate at 70℃ for 30 min. Ater centrifugation at 48,384 × g for 60 min, the supernatant was loaded onto a HisTrap HP column (Cytiva) and eluted with a linear gradient of 10–500 mM imidazole. Fractions containing TKSP114–539(S359A) were collected and dialyzed against 20 mM Tris–HCl, pH 8.0, 1 mM DTT, and 10 mM imidazole with TEV protease at 4℃ overnight for His-tag cleavage. The His-tag-cleaved TKSP114–539(S359A) was purified again using HisTrap HP column and then mixed with TKSpro at a 1:1 molar ratio. The resulting TKSP114–539(S359A):TKSpro complex was then loaded onto a HiLoad Superdex 200 column (Cytiva) equilibrated with 20 mM Tris–HCl, pH 7.5, and 150 mM NaCl. Peak fractions were pooled and concentrated up to 10 mg/mL using a Vivaspin 20 (Sartorius, Goettingen, Germany).

sec.title: Crystallization and structural determination of the TKSP114–539(S359A):TKSpro complex
sec.p:
Crystals of the TKSP114–539(S359A):TKSpro complex were obtained by the hanging-drop vapour diffusion method at 20℃. Drops containing 1 μL of protein solution and 1 μL of reservoir solution were equilibrated over 200 μL of reservoir solution containing 0.1 M HEPES–NaOH, pH 7.5, containing 1.5 M sodium acetate and 0.05 M cadmium sulfate. Crystals appeared within one week. Crystals were flash-cooled in a nitrogen gas stream after soaking in a cryoprotectant solution containing 0.1 M HEPES–NaOH, pH 7.5, containing 1.5 M sodium acetate, 0.05 M cadmium sulfate, and 18% (w/v) ethylene glycol. X-ray diffraction data were collected at beamline BL44XU at SPring-8 (Hyogo, Japan) under a cryogenic nitrogen gas stream. Diffraction data were processed and scaled using XDS (Kabsch 2010). The structure was solved by molecular replacement using MOLREP in the CCP4i suite (Winn et al. 2011), with the crystal structure of TKSP1–539 (S359A) (PDB ID: 3AFG), excluding the C-propeptide, used as the search model. Model refinement was carried out using Refmac5 (Murshudov et al. 2011) and PHENIX (Liebschneret al. 2019), with manual modifications using COOT (Emsley et al. 2010). The final structure was validated with MolProbity (Williams et al. 2018). Eight residues were flagged as outliers, but electron density in Fourier maps supported their conformations. At the achieved resolution, further refinement could not reposition these residues into allowed regions without compromising the overall model geometry. The data collection and refinement statistics are summarized in Table 1. The figures were prepared with PyMOL (http://www.pymol.org).Table 1

sec.title: Enzymatic activity measurement
sec.p: The proteolytic activity of mature TKSP was measured using N-succinyl-Ala-Ala-Pro-Phe-p-nitroanilide (Suc-AAPF-pNA; Cayman Chemical, Ann Arbor, MI) as described previously (Foophow et al. 2010b). Enzymatic reactions were performed at 37℃ in a buffer containing 20 mM Tris–HCl, pH 8.0, and 1 mM Suc-AAPF-pNA. IPTG-induced cells were harvested and resuspended in 50 mM Tris–HCl, pH 8.0, containing 1 mM CaCl2 at an OD600 of 15. After sonication and centrifugation, the extracts were incubated at 80℃ for 30 min to fully activate TKSP. Precipitated proteins were removed by centrifugation at 16,000 × g for 10 min, and the resulting supernatant was used for the assay. All solutions were pre-incubated at 37℃ for 5 min prior to reaction initiation, and the reactions were started by mixing 10 μl of protein solution with 90 μl of substrate solution. Proteolytic activity was monitored by measuring the increase in absorbance at 410 nm, corresponding to the release of p-nitroaniline, using a Varioskan LUX plate reader (Thermo Scientific, San Jose, CA). One unit of enzymatic activity was defined as the amount of the enzyme that produced 1 μmol of p-nitroaniline per min. Statistical data analysis was performed using SigmaPlot ver. 15.0.

sec.title: Inhibitory activity of propeptides
sec.p: The inhibitory potency of TKSpro and its derivatives was evaluated using Suc-AAPF-pNA, following the method described for the propeptide of pernisine, a hyperthermophilic subtilase (Bahun and Ulrih, 2023). Reaction mixtures contained 100 nM mature TKSP, 1 mM Suc-AAPF-pNA, and varying concentrations of propeptides (0–1000 nM) in 20 mM Tris–HCl, pH 8.0. The reaction progress at 37℃ was monitored by measuring absorbance at 410 nm. For data analysis, the progress curves were fitted to the equation for a tight and slow binding inhibitor (Williams et al. 1979). Initial velocities in the absence and presence of inhibitors from the curves were determined and denoted as v0 and vi, respectively. The apparent inhibition constant (Ki) was calculated from the slope of the plots of [propeptide]/(1 – vi/v₀) versus v₀/vi, as described by Szedlacsek and Duggleby (1995). Data fitting, calculation, and graph preparation were performed using SigmaPlot ver. 15.0 (Systat Software, San Jose, CA).

sec.title: Co-expression of TKSpro enhances mature TKSP yield in E. coli
sec.p: TKSP is an exceptionally stable protease with a broad substrate spectrum, and its cytotoxicity hinders overproduction in E. coli (Foophow et al. 2010b). BL21(DE3) cells transformed with pET25b-TKSP1–640 exhibited defects in colony formation, while those expressing the catalytically inactive mutant TKSP1–640(S359A) grew normally (Supplementary Fig. S2A), indicating that even basal expression of active TKSP is toxic to E. coli. Although the TKSP precursor includes an N-terminal propeptide (TKSPpro) that inhibits its catalytic domain, this was insufficient to prevent cytotoxicity in vivo. To address this, we attempted to mitigate intracellular proteolytic activity by employing an alternative propeptide. TKS, another subtilisin homologue from T. kodakarensis, possesses a stable N-terminal propeptide (TKSpro) known to inhibit its cognate catalytic domain (TKS70–398) even at elevated temperatures. Remarkably, co-expression of TKSpro rescued the growth defect caused by TKSP expression (Supplementary Fig. S2B). Based on this finding, we hypothesized that TKSpro might enhance TKSP expression by mitigating its cytotoxic effects in E. coli.

Because both BL21(DE3) and Rossetta 2(DE3) cells transformed with pET25b-TKSP1–640 showed severe growth defects, we utilized C43(DE3) cells, which are more tolerant to the toxicity of heterologously expressed proteins (Dumon-Seignovert et al. 2004). C43(DE3) cells harboring pET25b-TKSP1–640 formed colonies and grew in liquid media, albeit with a slower growth rate and markedly lower colony-forming efficiency (Fig. 1A and Supplementary Fig. S2C). Following IPTG induction, SDS-PAGE analysis of cell lysates, with and without heat treatment, revealed a 44-kDa protein band corresponding to mature TKSP (44 kDa) only in co-expression cells after heat treatment (Fig. 1B). A band corresponding to co-expressed TKSpro was detected before heat treatment but disappeared afterward, indicating that TKSP was fully activated through degradation of both TKSPpro and TKSpro. Proteolytic activity in the co-expression system was approximately five-fold higher than in cells expressing TKSP alone (Fig. 1C). The TKSP activity obtained from the co-expression cells eventually reached a ten-fold increase (0.270 ± 0.016 units) compared to that from EV cells (0.029 ± 0.001 units) in another independent experiment (see Fig. 3C). This variation in activity may reflect differences in the level of TKSP expression tolerated by individual cells. From a 1-L culture of co-expression cells, we successfully purified 2.7 mg of mature TKSP. In contrast, TKSP could not be obtained from cells expressing TKSP alone due to insufficient expression levels. These results demonstrate that co-expression with TKSpro effectively reduces TKSP cytotoxicity, thereby enabling its overproduction in E. coli and purification.Fig. 1
(A) TKSpro rescues the growth defect caused by TKSP. C43(DE3) was transformed using pET25b-TKSP1-640, pCDF1b (EV) and pCDF1b-TKSpro. (B) TKSP expression in a co-expression system. Supernatants of cell lysates before and after heat treatment (HT) were analyzed by 12% Tricine SDS-PAGE. (C) Proteolytic activities in cell lysates after heat treatment. Data represent mean ± SD (n = 4). Different letters indicate significant differences (One-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s test, p < 0.05)

sec.title: TKSpro binds tightly to mature TKSP in a substrate-like manner
sec.p:
TKSpro inhibits its cognate catalytic domain by binding to its active site cleft in a competitive manner (Tanaka et al. 2007a). To elucidate the molecular basis of TKSpro-mediated inhibition of TKSP, we determined the crystal structure of their inhibitory complex. For crystallization, we used TKSP114–539(S359A), generated by removing both TKSPpro and the C-terminal propeptide from a catalytically inactive precursor. The crystal structure of the TKSP114–539(S359A):TKSpro complex was determined at 3.2 Å resolution (Fig. 2A). The overall structure of TKSP114–539(S359A) in the complex closely resembles that of its unautoprocessed precursor (Supplementary Fig. S1), where TKSPpro remains covalently linked with the N-terminus of mature TKSP. The root mean standard deviation (r.m.s.d.) of Cα atoms between these two structures is 0.47 Å (Supplementary Fig. S3A). Likewise, TKSpro aligns well with TKSPpro from the unautoprocessed form with an r.m.s.d. of 1.73 Å, despite sharing less than 20% sequence identity (Supplementary Fig. S3B).Fig. 2
(A) Overall structure of the TKSP114–539(S359A):TKSpro complex. TKSpro is colored red. Subtilase and β-jelly roll domains of TKSP114–539(S359A) are colored green and yellow, respectively. The residues of catalytic triad (Asp147, His180 and Ala359) were shown as stick models. Calcium ions are shown by cyan spheres. N and C represent N- and C-termini. (B) Four C-terminal residues of TKSpro occupy the substrate binding pockets of TKSP114–539(S359A). The catalytic site is colored green. (C) Interactions between αβα substructure of TKSP114–539(S359A) and hydrophobic loop of TKSpro. The hydrogen bonds are shown as black broken lines

TKSpro interacts with TKSP114–539(S359A) primarily through two regions. First, its C-terminal residues extend across the active site cleft of TKSP114–539(S359A) (Fig. 2B and Supplementary Fig. S4A). TKSP114–539(S359A) forms hydrophobic substrate-binding pockets, termed subsites S1–S4, which fully accommodate the C-terminal four residues of TKSpro (Ala66–Leu69) in a substrate-like manner. Second, a hydrophobic β-turn loop (Phe33–Pro37) of TKSpro engages the lateral side of TKSP114–539(S359A) (Fig. 2C). In this region, Phe33, Lue35 and Ile36 of TKSpro form extensive hydrophobic contacts with multiple hydrophobic residues of TKSP114–539(S359A), and Asp230 and Asn266 of TKSP114–539(S359A) establish hydrogen bonds with the main chains of Lys34 and Leu35 of TKSpro. These interactions occur near two α-helices that constitute the αβα substructure essential for subtilase folding. Although similar interactions occur between TKSPpro and mature TKSP, the C-terminal region of TKSpro binds more tightly within the active site cleft. Notably, Leu69 of TKSpro is better accommodated by the large S1 subsite compared to Ala113 of TKSPpro (Supplementary Fig. S4B). These structural observations suggest that TKSpro is a more potent inhibitor of TKSP than its native propeptide.

sec.title: Binding of hydrophobic residues at the S1 subsite is essential for TKSP inhibition
sec.p: The S1 subsite of TKSP114–539(S359A) provides ample space to accommodate bulky hydrophobic residues (Fig. 2B). Based on this, we hypothesized that substitution of Leu69 in TKSpro could modulate inhibitory potency. To test this, we generated two TKSpro mutants, TKSpro(L69A) and TKSpro(L69W), in which Leu69 was replaced with alanine and tryptophan, respectively.

The inhibitory activities of wild-type and mutant TKSpro proteins were evaluated using Suc-AAPF-pNA as a substrate (Pulido et al. 2007a). Progress curves revealed slow-binding inhibition for all variants (Fig. 3A). The apparent inhibition constants (Ki) were determined to be 16 ± 1.3 nM for TKSpro, 62 ± 4.1 nM for TKSpro(L69A) and 7.8 ± 0.3 nM for TKSpro(L69W). These results clearly indicated that larger hydrophobic residues at position 69 enhances binding affinity to mature TKSP.Fig. 3
(A) Inhibition of TKSP by TKSpro and its derivatives. The hydrolysis of Suc-AAPF-pNA by TKSP was monitored by measuring absorbance at 410 nm at various concentrations of propeptides. The progress curves of enzyme reaction including 0, 20, 50, 100, 200, 500 and 1000 nM propeptides, are shown. (B) Proteolytic activities in cell lysates after heat treatment. Data represent mean ± SD (n = 4). Different letters indicate significant differences (One-way ANOVA followed by Tukey’s test, p < 0.05)

We next investigated how these mutations affected TKSP expression. Co-expression with TKSpro(L69W) increased TKSP yield compared to cells without a co-expressed propeptide, reaching levels comparable to those observed with wild-type TKSpro. In contrast, co-expression with TKSpro(L69A) leads to a four-fold reduction in TKSP activity (Fig. 3B). We eventually purified 2.1 mg of mature TKSP from 1-L culture medium by co-expression of TKSpro(L69W). These findings suggest that TKSpro effectively suppresses the cytotoxicity effect of TKSP during co-expression, thereby enabling its overproduction in E. coli. Although TKSpro(L69W) exhibits stronger inhibitory activity than wild-type TKSpro, the wild-type appears to be sufficiently optimized for supporting efficient TKSP expression.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Extracellular subtilases have broad applications across various industries. However, their heterologous expression in E. coli often faces significant production challenges. For instance, TKS tends to form inclusion bodies due to the insufficient intracellular Ca2+ concentration required for proper folding (Tanaka et al. 2007b). Another hypethermophilic subtilase from Aeropyrum pernix K1, termed pernisine, forms soluble aggregates in the cytosols (Bahun et al. 2020). Subtilase from thermophilic Bacillus sp. WF146, which contains the essential disulfide bonds, requires translocation to the periplasm to produce an active enzyme (Zhu et al. 2013). Even mesophilic subtilases, such as subtilisin E from Bacillus subtilis, can form inclusion bodies under crowded cytosolic conditions despite their Ca2+-independent folding (Chen et al. 2008). Unlike these subtilases, TKSP is produced in E. coli as a soluble and monomeric protein without any genetic modifications. However, the rapid activation of the TKSP precursor, which includes TKSPpro, results in the premature release of active TKSP, leading to severe cytotoxicity in host cells. A previous study on the crystal structure of the TKSP precursor suggested that TKSPpro binds tightly to TKSP as a competitive inhibitor (Foophow et al. 2010a). Nevertheless, even basal expression of the TKSP precursor severely compromises E. coli cell growth (Supplementary Fig. S2A), indicating that the inhibitory potency of TKSPpro is insufficient within cells. Notably, propeptides of mesophilic subtilases are known to be intrinsically disordered in the absence of their catalytic domains (Wang et al. 1998; Subbian et al. 2005). It is plausible that within cells, disordered TKSPpro may misfold and become susceptible to proteolysis by cellular proteases. Supporting this, SDS-PAGE analysis revealed that TKSPpro did not accumulate in either soluble or insoluble fractions when expressed alone (Supplementary Fig. S5), suggesting that it is unstable and degraded.

TKSpro is a unique propeptide that retains a folded structure even after dissociation from its cognate subtilase domain. Owing to its subtilase-independent folding, TKSpro can strongly inhibit mature TKS, forming a stable inhibitory complex even at temperatures up to 60℃ (Pulido et al. 2007b). In this study, we co-expressed TKSpro with TKSP to suppress the cytotoxicity associated with TKSP production. As expected, co-expression with TKSpro significantly increased the expression levels of TKSP, suggesting that inhibition of intracellular proteolytic activity is critical for the successful overproduction of TKSP. Notably, a structurally destabilized mutant, TKSpro(G56E) (Pulido et al. 2007a, 2007b), failed to rescue the growth defect caused by TKSP expression (Supplementary Fig. S6), emphasizing the importance of TKSpro’s structural integrity for effective inhibition.

Structural analysis revealed that the C-terminal Leu69 of TKSpro does not fit optimally into the spacious S1 subsite of TKSP (Fig. 2B). Consistent with this observation, the TKSpro(L69W) variant exhibited stronger inhibitory activity than the wild-type, whereas the TKSpro(L69A) variant showed weaker inhibition (Fig. 3B). Note that, in the precursor structure, TKSPpro occupies the S1 subsite with alanine (Foophow et al. 2010b), which may explain the insufficient inhibition of TKSPpro within cells. Although TKSpro(L69W) showed stronger inhibition, it did not further enhance TKSP expression beyond the level achieved by wild-type TKSpro, suggesting that the wild-type is already sufficiently optimized for supporting TKSP production under the tested conditions.

Although C-terminal engineering of TKSpro did not markedly improve TKSP expression in this study, such modification could potentially be beneficial for boosting the expression of other cytotoxic subtilases in E. coli. The binding mode of subtilases and their propeptides is highly conserved: propeptides complementarily bind their cognate catalytic domains primarily through the extended C-terminal region and the central β-turn loop. Since the release of active subtilase from the propeptide–subtilase complex is the rate-determining step in maturation, these interactions are finely tuned to prevent premature activation for each subtilase. Our previous work demonstrated that engineering the C-terminal residues of the propeptide can effectively modulate the inhibitory potency and consequently the maturation rate of TKS precursor (Uehara et al. 2013). In addition, the β-turn loop-mediated interactions have been shown to contribute to specificity, as exemplified by pernisine (Bahun and Poklar Ulrih 2023). Based on these findings, we hypothesize that the C-terminal residues and the β-turn loop of TKSpro are promising targets for tailoring its inhibition profile toward specific subtilases. Successful engineering of these sites requires a structurally stable scaffold. Due to its inherent rigidity, TKSpro could serve as a robust framework for such modifications. Finally, given that this co-expression strategy is inherently compatible with other approaches for enhancing subtilase production, such as codon optimization and membrane translocation (Šnajder et al. 2015; Bahun et al. 2020), combining these methods may further increase the yields of subtilases for industrial and biotechnological applications.
